headline: Apple Pie by Grandma Ople
description: This apple pie recipe makes a caramelized lattice crust for sweet, buttery apple slices. Serve warm with ice cream for the perfect holiday dessert!

video.description: Learn how to make Grandma Ople's apple pie.
video.name: Apple Pie by Grandma Ople

name: Apple Pie by Grandma Ople
recipeIngredient: 8 small Granny Smith apples, or as needed

recipeInstructions.text: Peel and core apples, then thinly slice. Set aside.
Preheat the oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).

Melt butter in a saucepan over medium heat. Add flour and stir to form a paste; cook until fragrant, about 1 to 2 minutes. Add both sugars and water; bring to a boil. Reduce the heat to low and simmer for 3 to 5 minutes. Remove from the heat.
Press one pastry into the bottom and up the sides of a 9-inch pie pan. Roll out remaining pastry so it will overhang the pie by about 1/2 inch. Cut pastry into eight 1-inch strips.
Place sliced apples into the bottom crust, forming a slight mound. Lay four pastry strips vertically and evenly spaced over apples, using longer strips in the center and shorter strips at the edges.

Make a lattice crust: Fold the first and third strips all the way back so they're almost falling off the pie. Lay one of the unused strips perpendicularly over the second and fourth strips, then unfold the first and third strips back into their original position.
Fold the second and fourth vertical strips back. Lay one of the three unused strips perpendicularly over top. Unfold the second and fourth strips back into their original position.
Repeat Steps 6 and 7 to weave in the last two strips of pastry. Fold and trim excess dough at the edges as necessary, and pinch to secure.
Slowly and gently pour sugar-butter mixture over lattice crust, making sure it seeps over sliced apples. Brush some onto lattice, but make sure it doesn't run off the sides.
Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce the temperature to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) and continue baking until apples are soft, 35 to 45 minutes.

I've been making this pie for 20 years-since I was a young married lady. The recipe was published in the "All Recipes Tried and True Favorites" cookbook and it has blessed my family for two decades. The only modification I make is minor-I sprinkle a tiny bit of cinnamon over the apples before I cover them with the latticework crust. Otherwise, I recommend baking as written. Do NOT mix the sauce with the filling. Pouring over the top as directed and baking at the initial high temp will result in a nice caramelized finish on the top crust and just the right amount of the sauce will drip down into the applies. I also suggest using a heavy glass pie dish and making sure you are working with a clean oven as I've found that thinner dishes and dirty ovens cause mischievous results (burning or dark spots in some areas, light in others). I have made this pie twice. I have a sweet tooth in general and don't tend to reduce sugar in recipes. Both times I added cinnamon to the apples and vanilla to the butter/flour/sugar mixture (and maybe a little salt to the caramel, don't remember), but I made no other changes. The first time I made this, it was absolutely perfect. It tasted like a caramel apple, but as a pie. I was so, so excited to have found this recipe. It was awesome. The second time around, I was super excited to make it again, but this time I didn't use Granny Smith apples, but other apples that were less tart than Granny Smith (though still generally pie apples, not sweet apples. I think they were Braeburn). That time, the pie still tasted .. ok, but it was not the perfect flavor balance. Since the apples were less tart than Granny Smith ones, the whole pie came out significantly too sweet for my taste and the flavor was too flat. The apples were also a lot softer and made the filling a bit too runny. That was a real shame. So I would strongly recommend to either only use Granny Smith apples for this recipe(or other apples that are just as tart) or to reduce the sugar by 1/4 or 1/3 of the listed amount if using other, less tart apples (like Elstar, Braeburn etc), and then maybe sprinkle the (non-Granny Smith) apples with a tablespoon of flour or cornstarch to prevent a watery filling. In my opinion this recipe would not work well with sweeter apples like Gala or Golden Delicious unless you just like intensely sweet things.
